(3) About Me

  • Ph.D. in Communications Systems [http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil97b] from ETH Zürich [http://www.ethz.ch/]
  • Working on Web Architecture after writing the first Web Technology book [http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil98]
  • UC Berkeley (2006-2011), working on Service Models for Open Government [http://dret.net/netdret/publications#wil09g]
  • EMC (2011-2014), working on transforming software products into service platforms
  • Siemens (2014-2015), working on using IoT to build WoT (APIs for Things)
  • Joined CA [http://www.ca.com/]'s API Academy [http://www.apiacademy.co/] in 2016 and now all about API Strategy and Design
  • Active in the usual places such as Twitter [http://twitter.com/dret], GitHub [http://github.com/dret], my blog [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/], LinkedIn [http://www.linkedin.com/in/netdret], and flickr [https://www.flickr.com/photos/dret/]

(8) API Excellence



Awesome APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(9) Excellence as a Service

  • What matters for an API Center of Excellence (CoE)?
    • Should excellence sit in CoE and be created/managed/delivered from there?
    • Should the CoE be a service to enable all teams achieving excellence?
  • API landscapes are ecosystems that need cultivation
    • Ecosystems value diversity to improve fitness over time
    • Cultivation is a continuous process of feedback and improvement
  • Culture evolves over time as a set of shared practices
    • Culture is a set of shared do and don't rules


Awesome APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(10) Web Culture: Webby Service Design



Awesome APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(11) Emerging Patterns

  • Self-description for APIs is increasing
  • Problem details [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/7807] as a way how APIs expose error information
    • Enables generic error handling but also allows additional information
  • Home documents [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/nottingham-json-home] as a way how APIs provide starting pages
    • Enables harvesting of API start points but also allows additional information
  • Healthcheck reports [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/inadarei-api-health-check] as a way how APIs expose status information
    • Enables landscape-level status reports but also allows additional information


Awesome APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(12) APIs and API Landscapes

  • Design Patterns make designing APIs easier
  • Design Patterns make navigating landscapes easier
  • Design Patterns are continually evolving vocabularies
  • Design Patterns should reflect product needs
    • Why a product should have certain properties/capabilities
    • What can be done to address these issues
    • How a team may choose to implement the resolution


Awesome APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(13) API Stylebook: Error Format



Awesome APIs Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(14) Excellent API Management → Awesome APIs

  1. Easy to design → Design Scope and Vocabulary
  2. Easy to implement → Useful Components
  3. Easy to discover → Rich Description
  4. Easy to use → Rich Documentation
  5. Easy to control → Connective Fabric Instrumentation
  6. Easy to combine → Coherent Designs
  7. Easy to change → Open Design
  8. Easy to withdraw → Lifecycle Thinking

Interface ≠ Implementation Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(16) Design and Constraints

Design depends largely on constraints. [http://www.markwunsch.com/eames] (Charles Eames [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_and_Ray_Eames])
  • Why are constraints driven by business and/or client needs
  • What should be design patterns addressing the constraints
  • How should be support/tools for implementing the what


Interface ≠ Implementation Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(17) APIs are Interfaces



Interface ≠ Implementation Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(18) Changing Culture

  • Microservices are changing the way APIs are implemented and managed
    • Velocity as the main goal
    • More design freedom for product teams (APIs and implementation)
    • More complex runtime needs (diversity requires operational excellence)
  • Enterprise IT has discovered loose coupling [http://dret.net/netdret/publications#pau09a] and called it Microservices
    • Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
    • Working software over comprehensive documentation
    • Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
    • Responding to change over following a plan


Interface ≠ Implementation Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

Example: API Change Management

Example: API Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(21) API Change Management in API Strategy

  • API change management becomes increasingly important
    • Microservices optimize for quick design/deployment/development/decommissioning
    • Even in MSA-land there are Experience APIs meant to deliver some API stability
  • APIs can change in terms of features and will be decommissioned at some point
    • Robust extensibility [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2016/04/robust-extensibility.html] helps to facilitate non-breaking API changes
    • Hypermedia helps as a pattern to move extensibility beyond data models
    • Semantic versioning [http://semver.org/] may be used to keep track of API changes
  • Always follow the why/what/how triad for API strategy
    • Why: Somebody (myself/consumers) is interested in how an API will change
    • What: Follow principles/patterns/protocols to manage/expose API changes
    • How: Support tooling/services to implement and test pattern behavior


Example: API Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(22) HTTP Sunset: An Even Simpler Example

  • API Documentation guidelines may ask for change management documentation
    • Requirement: Can be as simple as making documentation discoverable on deploy
    • Resolution: Can be as simple as stating that there is no change management
  • Discoverability and machine-readability are different issues
    • Making description resources discoverable can be validated during deployment
    • Every API entering the landscape must make change management documentation discoverable
    • For some classes of APIs/services additional requirements may be put in place
  • One possible requirement is that Public APIs must support Sunset [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Sunset]
    • Services must document/describe the support of Sunset
    • Services may implement Sunset any way they like
    • The simplest option may be Sunset policies on a gateway


Example: API Change Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness

(25) DevOps Your APIs!

  • APIs increasingly turn into central business assets
  • Do not mix interface and implementation issues
  • Have a lifecycle perspective of API management


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Achieving API Awesomeness
